introduction.p:
Early in our study of calculus in Section, we learned that if a function f has a derivative at a fixed value x=a, when we zoom in on its graph near (a,f(a)), the function looks linear. Indeed, such a function is differentiable, and we know that near a fixed input value a,
f(x) \approx L(x) = f(a) + f’(a)(x-a),
where L is the tangent line approximation to f at a.

figure.caption: The function f(x)=e^x and its tangent line L(x)=1+x near the point (0,f(0)).

introduction.p: We see at right in Figure that near the point of tangency, the approximation of f(x) = e^x by its tangent is quite good; at the same time, the tangent line and the function itself only agree exactly at the point of tangency, and as we see at left, we need not go far away from the point of tangency to have the difference between f and L be substantial.
It is natural to ask: can we find a simple function that approximates f more closely than L does and for more values of x near a = 0?

subsection.title: Finding a quadratic approximation
subsection.p: In Preview Activity, we found that a certain quadratic function can produce a better approximation to a given function f near a fixed point of interest. This idea is a natural generalization of the tangent line approximation. Next, we seek to understand how to find this well-chosen quadratic.

We know that for any function f that has a derivative at a=0, its tangent line approximation at a=0 is
L(x) = f(0) + f’(0)(x - 0)
Moreover, the functions L and f have two exact values in common. First, their function values agree at the point of tangency: L(0) = f(0). And second, since L(x) is a linear function whose slope is f’(0), it is also true that their derivative values agree at the point of tangency: L’(0) = f’(0).

To generate a quadratic function that approximates f near a = 0, we choose to have this quadratic function not only share the same function value and derivative value as f at a=0, but also (in order to match the concavity) the same secondHere we are implicitly assuming that the function f(x) has a second derivative at a=0. derivative value at a=0.
In Activity, we explore how these three requirements determine c_0, c_1, and c_2 in Q(x) for the function f(x) = e^x.
While we will develop this idea more formally in Section, the polynomial Q(x) that we found in Activity is called the degree 2 Taylor polynomial of f centered at a=0.

subsection.title: Over and over again
subsection.p: A remarkable feature of mathematics is that when a process effectively generates an approximation, doing that same process again (perhaps with some slight modifications) often improves the approximation. In Activity, we found a quadratic approximation of f(x)=e^x near the point (0,f(0)) that results in an improvement over the linear approximation of f. It is reasonable to hope that a degree 3 polynomial approximation of f(x) = e^x will be even better.

To investigate, we seek a degree 3 polynomial T(x) of the form
T(x) = k_0 + k_1 x + k_2 x^2 + k_3 x^3
that satisfies
T(0) = f(0), so T and f share the same function value at a = 0;
T'(0) = f'(0), so T and f share the same first derivative value at a = 0;
T''(0) = f''(0), so T and f share the same second derivative value at a = 0.
T'''(0) = f'''(0), so T and f share the same thirdHere we are assuming that the original function f has a third derivative at a = 0. derivative value at a = 0.

We also observe that since T is a polynomial, its derivatives are straightforward to compute. For instance, T'(x) = k_1 + 2k_2 x + 3k_3 x^2. We continue our investigation of this new approximation of f(x) = e^x in Activity, where we work to determine the values of k_0, k_1, k_2, and k_3 plus explore how well T(x) approximates f(x) near a = 0.
Like in the quadratic case, we’ll call the cubic polynomial T(x) degree 3 Taylor polynomial of f centered at a=0.

subsection.title: As the degree of the approximation increases
subsection.p: Our work so far suggests that, given the function f(x)=e^x, each time we increase the degree n of a polynomial approximation, T, that satisfies T(0) = f(0), T’(0) = f’(0), T’’(0) = f’’’(0), \ldots, T^{(n)}(0) = f^{(n)}(0), the accuracy of the approximation improves. This leads us to investigate further what happens when we increase the degree of the approximation.
